title: How long did it take to cross the silk road? - Quora

response.answer_text: The short version is “several months to over a year,” depending on exactly where you’re going and conditions along the way. The monk Xuanzang took about a year on the road to get from Chang’An (modern Xi’an), the Chinese capital and traditional beginning of the Silk Road to India, or rather eastern Afghanistan. A more westerly route, up the Gansu corridor to Dunhuang, across the Tarim Basin, to Kashgar, and across the mountains to Samarkand and the frontiers of the greater Persian cultural sphere is about 2300 miles. At around 11 miles a day—a reasonable rule of thumb for merchant caravan travel rates—that’s around 200 days. However, there are lots of potential delays along the way. For example, travel through mountain passes can be delayed for months by ice and snow in the winter.

That would depend on many things.. walking, by horse, leading a pack of camels a 1000 years ago or driving what you can of it today. BTW: the Silk Road wasn’t one road.. Below is a diagram of the 1st century Silk Road (s). Even that doesn’t show all the various side routes.
